name: Anonymous
com:
Web edition

>Free beginner resources to get started with HTML, CSS, JavaScript and PHP
https://eloquentjavascript.net/Eloquent_JavaScript.pdf - A modern introduction to JavaScript
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Learn - A good starting point to learn about web dev fundamentals
https://javascript.info/ - Quite a good JS tutorial
https://blog.javascripttoday.com - Awesome JavaScript/web dev blog.
https://www.theodinproject.com - Curriculum including HTML/CSS/JS, and either Ruby on Rails + SQL, or Node.js + MongoDB
https://fullstackopen.com/en/ - Requires you to have basic web dev, db and git knowledge
https://flexboxfroggy.com/ and https://cssgridgarden.com/ - Learn flex/grid in CSS
https://www.phptutorial.net - A PHP tutorial

>List of design resources
https://github.com/bradtraversy/design-resources-for-developers

>All useful documentation in one place
https://devdocs.io

>Need help? Create an example and post the link
https://jsfiddle.net - if you need help with HTML/CSS/JS
https://3v4l.org - if you need help with PHP/HackLang
https://codesandbox.io - if you need help with React/Angular/Vue

We have our own website: https://wdg.one
Submit your project progress updates using this format in your posts, the scraper will pick it up:

:: my-project-title ::
dev:: anon
tools:: PHP, MySQL, etc.
link:: https://my.website.com
repo:: https://github.com/user/repo
progress:: Lorem ipsum dolor sit amet

name: Anonymous
com:
>>94682312
Normies in general prefer an app for navigating content (shopping, social network, etc), so the only way a PWA would work is if Apple would allow TWAs into the App Store (which they don't).
In this case the only options left are hybrid and native (which you choose depending on how much money you want to invest).
The approach with turbo native is build two basic native apps (kotlin and swift), add the turbo native library on each and link the rails app url with different headers - this way the WebView intercepts actions and receive "DOM" updates as nodes the same way hotwire works in the browser. The only work you need on the rails app is a little tweak and ensure the website is responsive

name: Anonymous
com:
>>94687372
it boils down to the fact that you're always working with variables. starting with the very basics: You don't know for sure, that a client will download the .css and .js files that you linked in your html. However, suppose that it does, how do you know, that it handles them the way that you want? Everything that you send to the browser is merely a hint on what it should do. The browser is free to ignore your hints, it's free to modify them, but you still want stuff to work, don't ya? So what about screen sizes? Input devices? Are you dealing with a touch machine or a desktop?

name: Anonymous
com:
>>94684505
>Iwhat's the trend for
>2023
>2024
>2025
>...2030
Nodejs and whatever React flavor of the year is.
My guess is that Node or an equivalent JS backend runtime combined with React will stay the king and queen for at least the next 4 years. No new language can really compare if you are a smaller company who wants a language that lets you write code somewhat fast, be efficient enough and generally offer good enough type safety and have libraries that will solve the business needs.
Only C# or Java can really compare, to a lesser extent Python because of its bad type safety and too slow performance, but neither of them allows you to write code at the speed of JS. And for a startup and/or SMB this is quite important.

Newcomers are Golang and Rust, but they are not a good replacement in most cases. Other languages are too old and not cool enough to get people to work for you.
Maybe Hack, the Facebook developmed type safe version of PHP could make a big splash, but I really don't know anything about it, and few people want to work with PHP.

name: Anonymous
com:
something I found out I don't like about React
>multiple nested components that rely on a shared state
no problem, just create a context provider they can all access
>other set of components don't rely on the state but should be able to alter it
no problem, just let them also access the context provider
>two separate sets of components, two separate state sets they rely on, but they need to be able to alter each others' state
The headache begins. Now I have to create a monolithic context provider that has all their states defined directly for this to work. I'd like it if I could define separate sets of states with their own accessors for the provider to make things tidier, but instead I'm just defining all the state vars in one place and I have to organize them into sections using comments.

Plus, defining multiple providers in charge of their own state is out of the question because their relationship is only one way at best. One can only provide context for the other, not read it.

com:
const validURL = /^(https?:\/\/)?([a-z0-9]+(-[a-z0-9]+)*\.)+[a-z0-9-]+$/i;
const protocol = /^(https?:\/\/)/i;
if (validURL.test(urlValue)) {
    if (!protocol.test(urlValue)) {
        urlValue = "https://" + urlValue;
    }
}


Is there any better way to validate a url? To be specific I am looking for built-in features to avoid the regex stuff. My requirements are validating the url where it may or may not have a protocol. If the protocol does not exist, then append "https://" to the protocol.

name: Anonymous
com:
>>94713500
the URL constructor will do some validation for you but it doesn't catch everything
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/URL/URL
new URL("abcd"); // error
new URL("http/:/abcd"); // error
new URL("http//abcd"); // error
new URL("http:abcd"); // ok (probably not what you want though)
new URL("http://abcd"); // ok

what you could do though is something like this
const badUrl = "http:abcd";
try {
  if (!badUrl.startsWith("http://") || !badUrl.startsWith("https://") throw "Invalid URL";
  const url = new URL(badUrl);
  // url is ok if it gets to here
} catch (err) {
  // handle error
}

const res = await fetch(`http://${getApiUrl()}/comment/${comment.id}/`, {
  method: "PATCH",
  body: JSON.stringify(payload),
});
if (res.ok) {
  try {
    const data = await res.json();
    snackbar(data.message ?? "ok", "success");
  } catch (err) {
    snackbar(err, "error");
  } finally {
    setIsLoading(false);
  }
} else {
  try {
    const data = await res.json();
    snackbar(data, "warning");
  } catch (err) {
    snackbar(err, "error");
  } finally {
    setIsLoading(false);
  }
}

name: Anonymous
com:
Is it possible ot use a for loop for a property in scss?

I basically want 20 classes: --font-glow-strength-1, --font-glow-strength-2, --font-glow-strength-n ...etc. and each of these classes should have 
text-shadow: 0 0 4px black,
n times.
So basically:
--font-glow-strength-1 {
text-shadow: 0 0 4px black;
}
--font-glow-strength-2 {
text-shadow: 0 0 4px black, 0 0 4px black;
}
--font-glow-strength-3 {
text-shadow: 0 0 4px black, 0 0 4px black, 0 0 4px black;
}

etc.

I'm a newb at SCSS, I started like this, but inline @for doesn't work
    @for $i from 1 through 20 {
        --font-glow-strength-#{$i}: ...@for $j...
    }

name: Anonymous
com:
>>94723374
Nvm figured it out with the help of phind
@mixin create-classes {
    @for $i from 1 through 20 {
        &.font-glow-strength-#{$i} {
            $value : '';
            @for $j from 1 through $i {
                $value : $value + '0 0 4px var(--font-glow-color),';
            }
            text-shadow : unquote($value);
        }
    }
}
body{
@include create-classes;
}

Pls halp.

I'm using react routes to navigate to different pages. I'm fetching post data so that when I click on a button it takes me to a post page with the post data.

My function if working but I can't get the Link to to work with my onClick function to get the post data. When I click on the button, it takes me to the page but doesn't fetch the post data.

This is my code 

 
const BlogItems = ({ posts, post, setPost, getPosts }) => {
  const getPost = async () => {
    try {
      const response = await fetch(
        `http://localhost:3000/posts?id=${post?.id}`
      );
      const data = await response.json();
      setPost(data);
    } catch (error) {
      console.error(error);
    }
  };

  useEffect(() => {
    getPost();
  }, [post]);

  const onSetPost = (e) => {
    e.preventDefault();
    getPost();
    setPost(post);
  };
  console.log(post);
  const replace = post.title.replaceAll(' ', '-');

  return (
    <div>
      <div className='posts'>
        <div>
          <h2>{post.title}</h2>
        </div>
        <div>
          <p>
            <em>{post.body}</em>
          </p>
        </div>
        <Link to='/post' onClick={onSetPost}>
          <Button>View post</Button>
        </Link>
      </div>
    </div>
  );
};
